In keeping with the spirit of the Pathfinder revision, we're only making minor changes to the feats. If you have an earlier version of Megafeats, the older version of these feats still works fine. Forgeblood Feats have already been revised, and
are available as part of Thinking Races: Heroes of Iron and Steel.

A few feats have been excised entirely because they're too similar to how things work in the Pathfinder-revision by default or just because the new rules make them unnecessary. The Forge Gift Item Creation feats from Megafeats are gone, as are feats like Burning Belief (which let clerics deal direct damage with a turning check) and many of the variant "weapon and armor training" feats, hopefully proving the adage about great minds thinking alike.

Megafeats Revisited is intended as the largest collection of new feats available for the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game, more than doubling character options presented in either the first edition of Megafeats, or in the Pathfinder RPG core rules themselves! Many of the best feats from other Skortched Urf Studios and Otherverse Games products have migrated into this massive sourcebook.

The new feats in this sourcebook are inspired by a wide variety of sources - mythology, fantasy literature, comics, anime and even the way some other popular game systems do things. Hopefully, you'll find feats to fit your favorite tactics, and
some new ideas about what a role playing character can do over the course of a long, storied career.

127852.name: Soul Sacrifice
videogamehonor: 2013 Japan Game Awards Game of the Year Winner
127852.description:
The main protagonist of Soul Sacrifice is the slave that serves a powerful and cruel sorcerer. Just before the protagonist is going to be sacrificed, a demon in the form of a book appears before him. The book is a collection of stories that describe past fights between monsters and the powerful sorcerer. The player character is able to enter the book's world and experience the fights, thereby gaining experience and power.

The core mechanic of the game is the ability to sacrifice parts of the character's body or items to create devastating attacks. These sacrifices will be permanently marked on the player character's body, meaning that they are not an infinite resource that can be tapped into.

Source: Wikipedia, "Soul Sacrifice (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

127853.name: Pointless Wacky Untested Game I Made Up One Afternoon
127853.description:
INTRODUCTION:
Want to play a game that is literally untested, unproven, and that was made up one afternoon for a game contest? You've come to the right place then!

This is a game that makes absolutely no sense, but you may end up having fun anyway, just for spite.

So, roll up your sleeves and let's get started!

DESCRIPTION:
This game is primarily a party or icebreaker game where people take turns to try to complete challenges.

GAME OBJECTIVE:
Be the player with the lowest score at the end of the game

GAMEPLAY:
Players each receive tokens (of 4 varying colors), and then each player takes turns completing challenge cards. If a player is successful, they will generally reduce the number of tokens that they have (which are worth points). If a player fails a challenge, they will gain tokens. Each player is trying to gain the lowest score possible. Challenges are each very unique, and can be physical, logical, luck, or knowledge-based.

GAME ELEMENTS:

Light-hearted gameplay
Players can learn more about fellow players in a fun way
Token point system keeps everyone involved

127854.name: Phantom Brave: The Hermuda Triangle
127854.description:
The protagonist of Phantom Brave is a 14 year old girl named Marona. Having lost her parents at a young age, Marona lives on Phantom Isle in the land of Ivoire with a phantom named Ash. While he was still alive, Ash worked alongside Jasmine and Haze (Marona's parents) as a Chroma, a sort of bounty hunter. On an assignment at the Isle of Evil, a fragment of a malevolent being known as Sulphur attacked the group, mortally wounding them. Using the last of his life energy, Haze attempted to revive Ash after the battle. However, there was only enough life left in him to bring Ash back as a phantom. Haze and Jasmine's dying wish was for Ash to watch over their then-infant daughter Marona. Marona is the only one able to see Ash in phantom form.

Phantom Brave: The Hermuda Triangle is a port of the game Phantom Brave with added features.

Source: Wikipedia, "Phantom Brave", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

127855.name: Moving Day
127855.description:
UNPUBLISHED PRODUCT




it appears this Item will never be published

From the publisher website:

CMP 2011-01 – Moving Day

Extracting one person can be tough. Extracting an entire family? That’s on a whole different level. They say “Never deal with a dragon,” but maybe they should add “Never do a job involving grade schoolers and hormonal teens”!

127857.description:

127859.description:

127860.name: TRO 2073
127860.description:
UNPUBLISHED PRODUCT




it appears this Item will never be published

CMP 2011-06 – TRO 2073

It’s unwieldy, ungainly, and totally impracticable for modern warfare, but it makes for one hell of a publicity stunt. Ares needs a team of mercs to pilot and/or escort this so-called battlemech. Can the runners keep it in one piece and survive the opening round of Desert Wars 2073?

127861.description:
UNPUBLISHED PRODUCT

From the publisher website:

CMP 2011-07 – Super Brawl Sunday!

127878.name: Electro Comic
127878.description:
Electronic battery operated matching game has 10 different pages to play. When you match one picture on one side of the page to a picture on the other side of the page with the electric wands, a red light lights up at the bottom of the game to show that you are correct.

Player with the most correct answers is the winner.

127880.name: Exercises Snake Game
127880.description:
Exercises Snake Game is a gambling game. Players would put up stakes (money) to play and then divide the stakes according to the outcome of the game.

The game notes that it is "to be played with a tee-totum, or with dice."

The game has a snakes with number 1 near head and number 54 near the tail. The snake is laid out in s curves along the vertical direction. he sections of the snake are in different colors to show Charles Magnus' printing ability. The page is also decorated with men exercising for the same purpose. They have no absolutely no function in the game.

The special positions on the snake are colored red and are have special instructions.

2 - Gives the player two throws more
9 - 1 more throw
20 - Go back to No. 4
27 - Advance to 32.
33 - 1 more throw
40 - Gives the player one-half of all the stakes
46 - Stop for the next turn
52 - The player has lost and must cease to play
52+ - Those who throw over 52 divide the balance
of the stakes


More to "More"

This particular image found on the web was a sheet of paper which had the game on one side and a handbill advertising Charles Magnus' wares on the other. The handbill side indicates that this is one of 12 such games printed on a paper sheet and available for purchase.

127883.name: Colonies
127883.description:
The thriving colonies of Zel'var are the destination for many adventurous souls who choose to leave the solar system and good old planet Earth seeking a new life and good fortune – but not all find what they are looking for. Many become disillusioned, discontent even, and turn to pirating the prosperous trade routes between the five planets, much to the regret of the colonies' leaders, who have great need of the trade income in order to advance technologies and create jobs for the newly-arrived colonists.

Colonies is a game of resource management in the far reaches of space in which the players compete to dominate in trade, politics and technological development. Each player controls the administration of a planet with access to a unique resource. In order to win you need to collect the most colonial credits by trading resources, upgrading your technologies, keeping your trade lanes free of pirates, and perhaps pushing the council's decisions in the right direction.

At the begining of each turn, players receive an income of their own resource. The council meets each turn to vote on how to handle an occurring event. The outcome can reward those willing to put in an effort or punish those who are not. Players may do well to form alliances in order to sway the vote in a favourable direction.

The resource income and the colonists that arrive each turn – sometimes in large numbers, sometimes in small – are used to make advances in five areas: Community, Military, Commerce, Influence and Industry. Following the council's vote, players take turns to either upgrade these areas or activate one of them to grant asylum to pirates in exchange for resources or hunt them for bounty, sell resources for Credits, make trade agreements more beneficial, or produce additional resources. When everyone has had three such actions, the players receive and pay resources according to the trade agreements, and any colonists that players have failed to employ turn to piracy, preventing players from getting income from their trade agreements next turn unless preemptive action is taken.

Colonies lasts ten turns, with players earning victory points (VPs) from colonial Credits and technology advances. In the end, the player with the most VPs wins.

127889.name: Destination Lune
127889.description:
A children's game published in the French comic/magazine Francs Jeux.

The game has two boards. The first is a short Monopoly-style track. The aim is to land on squares featuring the six items that you need before you can try to fly to the moon. Movement is dictated by a die roll (you must supply your own die). The spaces you must land on to get these six things are:
T = Launching pad
F = Rocket
A = Apollo Capsule
L = Lunar landing module
J = Moon Buggy
E = Crew

When you have acquired these, you move to the second board. This is a traditional one track game (á la the Game of Geese). If you land on special spaces, you must obey the instructions. The first to get to the moon, wins.

127890.name: Disappearing Act
127890.description:
From the front page:

A One-Round Shadowrun Virtual Seattle Tournament

By Stephen Gabriel

From the Introduction:

The players are contacted by Claudia in the late hours of the work day, around 5am. She has a Johnson who needs a quick job accomplished; the players have roughly about 12 to 14 hours to do a clean up operation. The players are to meet the Johnson at the U-Store-All just south of the airport.

127892.name: Kopfball
127892.description:
Abstract two player game with a soccer theme. The player that scores more goals than the other after an agreed time wins.

Each player has a team consisting of 11 figures. The playing field consists of 83 spaces with connections between them. On each space there can only be one figure or the ball.

On each turn a player can kick the ball in a straight line if he has a player next to the ball and move one of his 11 figures one space. If a player cannot kick the ball he can move two figures one space each (or one figure twice).

There are some more rules like fouls, passing or kicking the ball over an opposing figure.

127902.name: X-It
127902.description: A dice and card game for two to four players. In your turn, you roll the dice and if you roll a total on one of your cards, you can discard it. If a player is dealt an "X-IT" card, it may be used as a wild card, i.e., 1 to 6. First to discard all their cards, wins. X-IT cards held by the losers, count as 6 points, other cards as at face value.

127903.name: Something Unholy Stirs
rpg: Old School Reference and Index Compilation (OSRIC)
127903.description:
From the front cover:

For people of the border town of Aldin, danger was a part of life. Savage beasts, extreme winters - these were things the people were prepared to deal with. What they weren't expecting to face was something so unholy that it was forbidden to speak of. Now a young group of would-be adventurers on their way to the large city of Halidor are forced to take refuge in Aldin due to a severe storm. Will they manage to escape ...

127904.name: Iron Storm (Saturn)
127904.description:
User Summary

Iron Storm is a WWII strategy game released exclusively on the Sega Saturn. The player chooses a WWII power to play as and then makes all of the key strategic decisions of the war. The game features over 50 scenarios, 500 unit types, and some of the first 3D graphics in a strategy game.

127906.name: Dark Refuge Core Rulebook
127906.description:
From the website:

Dark Refuge is a role playing game for both beginner and advanced Gamers. With a revolutionary new “Magic” system called The Leyas, all characters have their share of power. Unlike the limp-wristed mages of other game systems, characters in DR can use their magical abilities every round and are skilled warriors as well. Characters can Shapeshift their bodies, Summon monsters to their aid, and turn their Enemies powers against them. Set on the planet Refuge, a world of lost technology and high magic. Easy to play, Dark Refuge will appeal to gamers of all backgrounds. The Revised Edition clarifys rules, has additional monsters and gear and expanded information on the Colonies of Refuge. With the fastest paced combat and magic system to date, Dark Refuge the Adventure Game is a must have for all gamers.

This book provides unique, easy to learn game mechanics and a setting that stands on the edge between Sci-Fi and High Fantasy, complete with its own expansive mythology. Great for the casual gamer, who is looking for a fun way to spend a night with friends. Yet it allows a level of customization of characters that will keep the hardcore gamer playing for years.

127907.name: The Outlaws Guide to Refuge Sourcebook
127907.description:
From the website:

This Expansion for the Dark Refuge Game opens up the Criminal Underworld of Refuge. Expanded rules include the Nightmare Moors campaign setting, Illegal and Legal Drugs, the Assassins' Guild and Thieves' Guild, Vampyr-Vampire Life cycle and new Skills and Powers.

20+ New Player Characters including the Hydraulic Knights, Zombie Hunter, Guild Assassin, Necromancer and Drug Runner.

40+ New Enemies including the infamous Brethren Anton Davies, the Shadow Assassin Lust, the cloned Necromancer Lurlock and the armies of the Uth Warchief Zar'cos.

A Must for Player who want to expand their Fallen powers and Explore the Nightmare Moors.

127908.name: The Northern Kingdoms Sourcebook
127908.description:
From the website:

The Letters from the Border Wars

The Northern Kingdoms Guide expands the Dark Refuge Game opening up an entire new land for your players to explore and conquer.

Not only are the Northern Kingdoms full of opportunities for adventures as Kings and Queens. It has an Armory full of New Battleships, Submarines, and Airships all powered by a mixture of Magic and Technology. Complete with stats for many new types of Slave-soldiers to serve them, this guide is the ultimate pleasure for the Dictator in training.

This Guide also introduces the WarGiants. These WarGiants are massive monsters; Giants, Dragons and Sea Serpents that have been lobotomized and fitted with Cockpits built right into their skull. These WarGiants are powerful Warmachines, customized by their Pilots.

New Freedom Fighter Character Classes, including the Former PeaceLord, Failed Slammer, and Olgog Anarchist. New Peacebringer Character Classes, including the War Giant Pilot (complete with WarGiant) and Dragon of Borvis. New Mercenary Character Classes, including the Cyborg (complete with cybernetic upgrades), and Tarrisian Mutant.

This Sourcebook also includes a new Leyas training; Technomancy, which allows the user to hijack enemy vehicles, create Spy Drones and Nanites.

127909.name: The EEF Source Book Revised Edition
127909.description:
From the website:

The Military and Space Expansion for Dark Refuge the Adventure Game. This supplement has the rules for playing as a Soldier in the Earth Expeditionary Force, the defenders of the Colonies of Refuge. Expand your character by training with the Special Forces.

Learn to pilot one of the EEF Striders; Mecha that can make short work of a Tank. Defend the seas of Refuge in the EEF Navy, as the captain of a Submarine, Battleship or Airship. Dare the edges of Space with the Colonial Marines and the Project:Darkside Commandos.

Many new classes including the Power Armored Oni, and the Gunpod flying Valkyries. 30+ New Vehicles including Subs, Battleships, Airships, and Mecha. Multiple new starships, including starfighters, space transports and Capital Ships New Enemies including the stats for Iron Republic Brethren and the Iron Republic Fleet, the Space Pirates of Lost Hope space station, and the Sephir Mekanoid Empire.

127910.name: Border Wars: Aftermath
127910.description:
From the website:

This sourcebook helps you turn the 52 Weeks of Free Downloadable Border Wars Events into between 3 and 5 Years worth of adventures.

This supplement has the rules for playing as a Soldier in each of the New Factions. There are many new player created factions as well as ones created by the D.R. Team. Expanding the Lore of Refuge, Border Wars:Aftermath details the events of a chaotic year, 2217, when the Border Wars between the Northern Kingdoms of I'tash and the Earther Colonies finally ended.

Many new classes including the Balancer, and the EEF Exorcist. Many new player-created classes including The Bastard SpringRat, The Phantom & the Panzer Knight. New Vehicles including Capital Ships, Airships, Starships and WarGiants, including the unique city-class WarGiant- The Colossus of Beacon City. New Enemies including the stats for Unity Praetorians, Wintermute Blight Guard and the Fort Lendill Variable Starfighters.

Adds New Player-led Kingdoms to the Northern Kingdoms Campaign setting:

- The A'taru Asylum
- Beacon City
- Fort Lendill
- The Quantum Gate
- The Undead Kingdom of Wintermute

Adds new Player Created Factions:

- The Unity
- The Sons of Yantuk
- The Lions of Earth
- The Angels of Desolation

Adds Rules for New alien Speaking Races:

- The K'ias
- Warmonger's Dead
- The Quall N'fel

127911.name: The Complete Leyas Spellbook
127911.description:
From the website:

This quick-reference and rules supplement has all the Dark Refuge Leyas Abilities and Rules for incorporating the Leyas Spell System into other styles of RPG. Filled with situational experiences on how to use this spell-system with the player's environment.

All Elemental Leyas, Trained Leyas, Transcendental Leyas, including Technomancy and the secret final level of Troubadour training, the powers of the Song Mancers.

Includes stats for all Summoned Creatures.

127912.name: Desperate Remedy
127912.description:
From the Introduction:

I keep a well-stocked cellar of ready-to-run fantasy adventures, and Desperate Remedy is a particularly reliable example: ready in minutes, a perfect chameleon in terms of morality and tone, and built on a nonlinear foundation which gels perfectly, every time, into a structure of the players' own devising.

This is sort of a micro-module, and also sort of a deconstructed adventure seed. In the interest of providing a concrete, immediately-useful adventure, I've reigned myself in when it comes to exploring the (thousands?) of variations at every design-juncture. Veteran GMs will spot them immediately; novices can look forward to learning them as they go, everytime this adventure meets a band of PCs.

The premise is dirt-simple: someone has fallen strangely ill, leaving a loved one desperate with worry. A wise soothsayer has declared that he knows the magic cure, but that it requires some unusual ingredients. The PCs are entrusted to gather these items. The clock ticks, and the hunt is on!

There are a small handful of "blanks" to be filled in before the adventure is ready to run. They are the Beastie, the Victim, the Bereaved, the Soothsayer, the Ingredients, the Obstacles, and the Final Challenge.

Many are optional (the Final Challenge in particular), or may be combined. For each, I've provided examples from games I've run using Risus/Uresia (Uresius) and Encounter Critical. Since each world is a reflection of the other, you'll find (as I have) that each element swaps neatly across the conceptual membrane. Mix, match, replace and mutate... and run!

127914.name: Starship Defense
127914.description:
"The tower defense genre shifts into outer space! Defend your space fleet from enemy waves across 30 levels.

STARSHIP DEFENSE takes the tower defense genre into outer space! Defend your space fleet from wave after wave of enemy attacks by equipping a variety of weapons and using a combination of strategic skills and resource management. Attach weapons to your ships using the Touch Screen, making sure to place them for maximum effect when planning your defense—if you don’t, the relentless nature of your enemies could overwhelm you. Increase your chances of success by using energy collected from defeated enemies to install new and more powerful weapons, destroying particular enemies to obtain weapon upgrades, and watching for rare power crystals that unlock advanced attacks, including a devastating black hole! And if you still find yourself in trouble, select an SOS card to call on a special kind of assistance. You’ll have to defend your fleet across 30 intense sectors, some with specific challenges, while advancing your rank from lowly recruit all the way to fleet admiral. Are you up to the challenge?"

Source: The Publisher Website.

127915.name: The TFOS Yearbook '93
127915.description:
From the back cover:

In these pages, you'll find a horde of students for every occasion! Over nineteen of them, ready to be added to your Teenagers From Outer Space game! Rivals, romantic interests, odd aliens, even odder humans! Small fuzzy critters with automatic weapons!

127917.name: The Secret of the Dead Man's Satchel
rpghonor: 2011 Indie RPG Award - Supplement of the Year - Runner-Up
127917.description:
From the PDF:

The Secret of the Dead Man's Satchel is a short adventure for the Macabre Tales roleplaying game. The protagonist of the tale receives a mysterious package in the mail -- a satchel containing papers with strange encoded text. That's when his life begins to spiral out of control. Who sent the package? What does the coded text mean? What vile and sinister forces are at play? Will the character be able to get to the bottom of the situation before he is consumed in darkness?

127918.name: A Translation of Evil
127918.description:
From the PDF:

A Translation of Evil is a short adventure for the Macabre Tales roleplaying game. What if it were possible for a book to actually be evil? What if the written words themselves had the ability to inflict harm upon the reader? If so, how do you fight something that is, in essence, only an idea on a page? Will the protagonist succeed in translating this vile tome or will his fate be far more sinister?

127919.name: Modern Architecture Game
127919.description:
Trivia game in the architecture domain.

Basically Trivial Pursuit but with questions about architecture, architects, and building technique. There is a similar board type with the looks of a round technical drawing. The pawns are a famous building each. There several type of questions; famous buildings, architects, quotes and images.

The main goal is to reach the center of the board by answering trivial questions of cards that relate to the place of the pawn.

127920.description:
It was the age of gods and goddess. Zeus (King of the Gods), Poseidon (Lord of the Seas), and Hades (God of the Underworld) had agreed to separate the sky, the ocean, and the underworld. Athena, the Goddess of Wisdom, would take over the rest of the earth. But the Norse gods were displeased by the decision. They called warriors and disciples to take the world from the Greek gods. The gods atop Mt. Olympus also called their warriors to defend them. During this war of the gods, a mass of warriors died, and their souls were sealed in a jar.

And now they are waiting for you to release them.

In the deck-building game Kanzume Goddess, you will be one of the Gods of mythology. Each God in the game has its own special powers which players can use to their benefit. Players will purchase cards from the center of the table to add to their decks. They will use these cards to purchase more cards and to do battle with the other players. These cards can be used to damage other players, to gain more cards, to draw more cards from your deck, and to protect yourself from damage. The last player with energy left is the last God standing and the winner of the game.

Kanzume Goddess can be played as an individual match with 2-6 players or as a team match if you play with 4 or 6 players.
127920.name: Kanzume Goddess
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode 56 - Into the Galactic Arena

127921.name: TOTEM
127921.description:
The aim of TOTEM is for your chief to build their totem pole before the other chiefs do, but it's not as easy as it sounds!

Players first decide how high totem poles need to be to win, between one and four totems, with higher poles meaning longer games. Cards in TOTEM come in three colours, representing the spirit power associated with them - red = power of destruction, yellow = power of protection, green = power of creation. Players are dealt at random a card representing their chief, and a spirit card (which is not looked at), which can be used as a risky last resort to destroy other player's totems, but can backfire and destroy yours (if the spirit card doesn't match the colour of the chief using it).

Players then take turns to turn over and collect totem part cards. To build a totem, players need to collect three cards, a wood, tools and paint card, in the same colour as their chief. Once they do this they discard those cards and choose a totem in their colour to add to their pole. There are several totem designs for each colour, so players can customize the way their totem pole looks.

Some cards in the totem parts deck are Magic Items - if a player picks one of these up and it is in their chief's colour, they can use it to do various things, from destroying other players' hands of cards (the Tomahawk), to preventing other players using magic items (the Teepee), or allowing them to look at other player's cards and swap any they want to (Pipe of Peace).

Once a player has created the set number of totems, they need to finish off by creating a Totem Topper (collect a wood, tools and paint card in each of the three colours in any order), and then they win! But play can continue to determine other placings.

Components:
Totem Parts (42 cards - wood, tools, paint, plus 6 Magic Items)
Totems (24 cards - 8 destruction, 8 protection, 8 creation, all double sided)
Chiefs (6 cards - 2 destruction, 2 protection, 2 creation)
Spirits (6 cards - 2 destruction, 2 protection, 2 creation)
Totem Toppers (3 cards, double sided)

127922.name: Shadows and Ash
127922.description:
From the text:
While nurturing your memories the storm bells toll, exposed you had no warning. The lost are coalescing in the shadows.

User Summary:
Shadows and Ash is a re-theming of the minimalist game skeleton, Ghost/Echo. Players exist in an afterlife inspired by Wraith: The Oblivion.

The principle resolution mechanism is to roll 1d6 for each danger and for each goal, then to assign results. 65/43/21 = good/mixed/bad outcomes.

127923.name: War, Inc.
127923.description:
From the text:
your combat taxi is scattered over half a klick, your handler is screaming for the mission objective, Opfor is zeroing in, and DMZ Tv just went live. It is prime tme. [sic]

User Summary:
War, Inc. is a re-theming of the minimalist game skeleton, Ghost/Echo, into a future world of televised mercenaries akin to SLA Industries.

The principle resolution mechanism is to roll a d6 for each danger and for each goal, then to assign results. 65/43/21 = good/mixed/bad outcomes.

127924.name: Think Trunk
127924.description:
Think Trunk is the perfect group and party game. Its unique game play allows for everyone to be involved on every turn.

There are 5 different categories on each card: Think It, Number It, Act It, Prefer It, and Wing It. All 5 categories encompass and expand on current games on the market but are adapted for multi-player input without teams.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get to the end and a single round takes 20-30 minutes.

127925.name: Kobold Quarterly (Issue 22 - Summer 2012)
rpgissuearticle: Elven Archer Magic: 19 New Spells for Eagle-Eyed PCs
Game Theories: The GM's Influence on Character
Howling Tower: Total Party Kill or Total Buzz Kill?
Kobold Diplomacy: What's Right for the Game
A Pathfinder Society Guide to Varisia
Weapons for a New Age : 3 Black Powder Variants
127925.description:
(Front Cover)

Barbatos : Golarion Arch-Devil

Varisia: Pathfinder Society

Preview : 13th AGE

New Archer Spells (PFRPG)

Firearms (AGE)

the dragons steamhall * 15 magic dwarven rings * clockwork stalker * ecology of the dragonkin * interrogations * scaling combat feats * 9 monsters for castles & crusades * jason buhlman q&a * howling tower * ask the kobold * contest winner * and much more!

127926.name: Dueling Dice
127926.description:
Roll the Master Die to determine the "Point", then its off to the races as everybody rolls their 3 dice at once to score first! Roll High, Low, Odds, Evens, 3 of a Kind, or a Straight to win.

Roll the Master Die to determine what everyone is rolling for: odds, evens, three low, three high, low straight, or high straight. Players all roll at the same time and each player may "hold out" die as they roll the correct number. For example if you are going for "odds" and you roll a 1, you can place it aside and keep rolling to get the 3 and the 5. First player to get the correct roll, moves his/her marker along the score track. First to the finish, wins.

127927.name: Summoning Room
127927.description:
From the Introduction

Somewhere high above the ground lies this foreboding summoning room. The narrow arrow slit windows let little light in and do a bad job at keeping the cold howling wind out. The rooms only exit is a steel reinforced wooden door, but its dominating features are a large brazier on a raised platform at the back of the room, its flames rising high, and a large summoning circle in a sunk section of the floor which takes up most of the room. The summoning circle blazes in a downright infernal light and the heat it emits distorts the air.

127928.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Anti-tank squads are an essential element of modern infantry formations, and the Dust Tactics: Red Guards Anti-Tank Squad are a core element of the famed Red Guards Infantry Regiments. These veteran soldiers have spent countless hours perfecting their use of heavy weapons and aren't afraid to get up close and personal with the world's biggest war machines. If they get into range, there’s nothing they can't destroy.

These anti-tank specialists come equipped with two PTRS-47 bazookas, each capable of punching a hole through even the most heavily armored walkers. Deploy these soldiers to add some spine and versatility to any Dust Tactics SSU army!
127928.name: Dust Tactics: Red Guards Anti-Tank Squad – "Red Thunder"

127929.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Long behind the Axis and Allies in VK technology and combat walkers, the SSU army of Dust Tactics has relied on the strength of its infantry to endure the war, and Soviet field officers have been no strangers to their nation's suffering. Accordingly, though the Red Guards Command Squad offers SSU players all the standard Command Squad skills, allowing them to reactivate your other units, call in artillery strikes, and help coordinate your attacks, these stalwart veterans arrive at the battlefield better armed than their Axis and Allied counterparts. This squad means business!

These battle-tested soldiers have upgraded their weaponry to better combat any direct threat they might encounter. The Red Guards Command Squad carries UGLs and a PTRS-47 for the times when it's best to lead by example. After all, these soldiers are more than just a group of tough officers and specialists: They are First Red Guards.
127929.name: Dust Tactics: Red Guards Command Squad – "Red Command"

127930.description:
Game description from the publisher:

With less access to VK-driven technologies, SSU engineers have had to invent other means to combat the powerful walkers deployed by their Axis and Allied foes. Their response? The Dust Tactics: IS-5 Heavy Tank comes equipped with serious SSU firepower in both of two Damage Resilient configurations.

Built to deal with serious threat of enemy aircraft, the Mao Zedong controls a battlefield at range with its Quad 85 mm AA Gun. These powerful guns are deadly to enemy aircraft and can be used effectively against ground targets as well.

Meanwhile, the SSU has long considered artillery the most important weapon on the modern battlefield. Since the beginning of the war, fielding these huge guns has proven a successful tactic for the Soviets, one which they see no reason to stop now. The second configuration of the IS-5, the Vladimir Lenin, is a powerful artillery platform, capable of reducing enemy targets to rubble with its massive 252 mm field mortar.
127930.name: Dust Tactics: IS-5 Heavy Tank – "Mao Zedong / Vladimir Lenin"

127931.name: Wege des Entdeckers
127931.description:
(from the back of the book)
not only exploring dark dungeons or the liberation of kidnapped princesses is a major challenge in the life of a hero. travel itself is. Countless treasures and ancient mysteries still awaitdiscovery, guarded by terrible beasts or aboriginal tribes, and often it is necessary to reach distant and unknown regions to find them.

In Aventuria there are still areas that are only insufficiently researched and require experienced wilderness lore: the steaming jungles of the south, the snow-covered plains of the Far North, the sky-high and barren peaks of the Brazen Sword, the vast expanses of tundra, or the impenetrable forests of the Middle Empire. Other continents like the distant Myranor or Uthuria lure the explorers, as are unknown worlds and globules, and the dangerous, ever-gray limbo.
Wege des Enrdckers deals with many aspects of travel: How do you feed yourselve by hunting and gathering, what is a good bed and what to consider when creating a campfire? How do you prepare before a journey into the unknown, and what can happen on the way? Where can I get a local guide and information on residents and dangers of the area?
It is therefore suited for all games not featuring cities.

127932.name: Wet Work
127932.description:
From a convention description:

A team of runners intercepted a package, but the Johnson fumbled the ball. Now, you've been brought in to clean up the mistake.

A one session Virtual Seattle game for 4 - 6 runners, called in as part of a specialist team. Written by Stephen Gabriel.

127934.name: Die Reise durchs Märchenland
127934.description:
Objective: Be the first moving up to field 80
- moving by turns -
throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a red marked space follow instructions.

127935.name: Gänseliesel
127935.description:
Objective: Be the first moving up to field 70
- moving by turn -
throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a red marked space follow instructions.

127936.name: Midway
127936.description:
Operational level wargame for the battle of Midway in World war 2 Pacific theater.
This game published with Japanese history and military magazine "Rekishi Gunzo" #114 the Twenty Anniversary Issue. And also published along with Tsushima.

Players control either Imperial Japanese fleet or United States fleet.
Each player choose and resolve one of seven actions alternately. The seven actions is search, deck work, air sortie, resolve of air raid, mission abort, repair and additional damage check.
Unlike many other games, the grid map and unit movement are not include in this game. The game is progress by the viewpoint of the fleet commander.

Winner is determined by the damage given to enemy fleet and airbase each other, but Japanese player must given at least 6 points of damage for Midway airbase.

127937.name: National Trust Golf
127937.description:
Not confirmed on the box, but this must have been a promotional game for the National Trust, maybe to sell in their souvenir shops exclusively.

It is a simplicated table golf game, with marbles acting as golf balls and a cheap plastic golf hole, a flag (to add realism perhaps!) and a club for each player.

Set the hole somewhere on the table and whack a marble with your club. The fewest shots taken, wins.

I think you will need a spirit-level because slightly sloping tables and marbles don't go together very well.

Game is housed in a plastic pouch rather than a box.

127938.name: Kiyomori Gunki: Hogen and Heiji Rebellion
127938.description:
Issue game of Wargame Japanese History #12.

Operational level wargame on Hogen and Heiji rebellions during Japanese Heian period.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hōgen_Rebellion
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heiji_Rebellion
This game include two scenarios for each rebellion and two type campaigns for combined rebellions.
A "gunki" is a war story (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunki_monogatari).
Kiyomori is a famous Heian period person.

The game map covers city of Kyoto for movement and combat. It also includes main part of Japan for reinforcement march.
Each unit represents a lord (daimyo) or samurai warriors (retainers). All units has a battle rating and belong to one of the four clans. The clan is affect for unit activation and special ability. Certain lords (daimyo) have also special abilities.

Players control one side of each rebellion. Most side contains more than one clan.
Each turn players determine active clan by die roll. Activated unit are flipped down at end of their activation. So each unit can only activate once per turn, but Fujiwara clan's special ability allows them to reactivate flip down units.

Winner is determined by several victory condition per scenario. For example, elimination of highest lord, occupation of important areas, etc.

127939.name: BrainBox: Deutschland
127939.description:
This is a Germany-themed BrainBox game.

Description provided by the publisher:

Do you know which regions the river Rhine flows through Or where the Nürburgring is? BrainBox All Around Germany contains 69 beautifully-illustrated cards showing the very best Germany has to offer, and then some! The object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept and the person with the most number of cards after 5 or 10 minutes is the winner. Made from a minimum of 70% recycled material, the BrainBox range is fabulous fun. Find out who the BrainBox is in your family – it may not be who you think it is!

127940.name: BrainBox: Voyage en France
127940.description:
This is a France-themed BrainBox game.

Description provided by the publisher: Do you know where Mont St Michel is? Or where Camembert comes from? BrainBox All Around France contains 53 beautifully-illustrated cards showing the very best France has to offer, and then some! The object of the game is to study a card for 10 seconds and then answer a question based on the roll of a die. If the question is answered correctly, the card is kept and the person with the most number of cards after 5 or 10 minutes is the winner. Made from a minimum of 70% recycled material, the BrainBox range is fabulous fun. Find out who the BrainBox is in your family – it may not be who you think it is!

127942.name: Ambulance
127942.description:
From the box:

"Race your ambulance through the city to save ailing citizens. Avoid cars and approaching trains while making use of your emergency shelters. Score points for safe patient deliveries. Faster deliveries get more points!"

127943.name: One Page Dungeon Contest 2010: The Winning Entries
127943.description:
From One Page Dungeon Contest 2010 website:

Judges had one month to read all the submissions and another two weeks to discuss the result.

Here’s how we determined the winners:

Every judge nominated twenty entries and proposed a category or tag for each.
We prepared a list of the entries that got three or more nominations. These are the nominations.
Every judge again picked five entries from this smaller list.
All entries getting three or more votes are the judge’s picks.
We tried to make sure that every judge had at least three of his picks in the final list. Judge with an eclectic taste may find that not many of their nominations made it into this list. As the idea is to not only reflect popular opinion but to also capture some of the more eclectic entries out there, judges may add additional submission to the judge’s picks until we feel that every judge is well represented. We’ll try to aim for three entries per judge.
Based on the categories proposed in the first step, we assigned a category to each entry on the list.
The result was our release candidate 1. Judges got to check whether their favorites are still on the list.
We fix omissions and rename categories until we’re happy. This is our release candidate 2.
We revise everything until we’re happy. We have our list of winners!




Winners:





Entry

Winning Category



Adam Thornton – Central New Jersey After the “Big Whoops”

Best Post Apocalyptic Goodness



Antti Hulkkonen – Den of Villainy

Best Pirates



Chris Gonzales – The Tunnels of Turrack the Terrible

Best Sound Effects



Clarabelle Chong – Time for Tea

Best Victorian Sci-Fi



Corwin Riddle – City of Traitors

Best Lost City



Craig Brasco – The Vault of Zerduzan

Best Evil Cultist Hangout



Heron Prior – Trolls will be Trolls

Best Lair



Herwin Wielink – The Crypt of Luân Phiên

Best Architectural Design



Jimm Johnson and Jeff Lynk – The Contemptible Cube of Quazar

Craziest Map Award



Lord Kilgore – Heart of Darkness

Best Mini Campaign



Paul Siegel – Four Corners

Best Fitness Center



Peter A. Mullen – Laboratory of the Asmodean Techno-Mage

Snazziest Way to Push the Envelope



Rob Antonishen – Mine! Not Yours?

Best Mine Crawl



Shane Mangus – Raid on Black Goat Wood

Best Cthulhu



Simon Bull – The Ruination Of Tenamen

Best Monsters



Stuart Robertson – Dungeon From A Distant Star

Best Mixing of Genres



Tim Shorts – Where is Margesh Blackblood

Most Hideouts for the Head Bad Guy



Tom Holmes – The Bone Harvest Horror

Best Cartography

127944.name: Ant Eater
127944.description:
"A similar game, Ant Eater, was released by Romox[4] for the Commodore VIC-20, Texas Instruments TI-99/4A and Atari 8-bit home computers but, while it was inspired by Anteater, it plays differently[2]."

Source: Wikipedia, "Anteater (video game)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

127945.name: Bigfoot (TI-99)
127945.description:
User Summary:

Object of the game is to climb past obstacles, including Bigfoot himself, to the summit of a mountain where a cage can be lowered to capture Bigfoot.

127946.name: One Page Dungeon Contest 2011: Winners
127946.description:
From One Page Dungeon Contest 2011 website:

Judges had one month to read all the submissions and another two weeks to discuss the result.

Here’s how we determined the winners:

Every judge nominated twenty entries and proposed a category or tag for each.
We prepared a list of the entries that got three or more nominations. These are the nominations.
Every judge again picked five entries from this smaller list.
All entries getting three or more votes are the judge’s picks.
We tried to make sure that every judge had at least three of his picks in the final list. Judge with an eclectic taste may find that not many of their nominations made it into this list. As the idea is to not only reflect popular opinion but to also capture some of the more eclectic entries out there, judges may add additional submission to the judge’s picks until we feel that every judge is well represented. We’ll try to aim for three entries per judge.
Based on the categories proposed in the first step, we assigned a category to each entry on the list.
The result was our release candidate 1. Judges got to check whether their favorites are still on the list.
We fix omissions and rename categories until we’re happy. This is our release candidate 2.
We revise everything until we’re happy. We have our list of winners!




Winners:





Entry

Winning Category



Meckwick’s Revenge by Aaron Frost & Mundi King

Best Dungeon as Thunderdome



Into the Worm’s Gullet by Dyson Logos

Best Old-School Dungeon



The Bastion of the Boglings by Greg Gillespie

Best Monster Lair



Hallways of Thime by Herwin Wielink

Best Map Art



Raid on Chinatown by Jason Morningstar

Best Gangster



The Heart of the Minotaur by Joe Sarnowski

Best Twist to an Adventure



Horror Comes to Haddonfield by Kelvin Green

Best Horror



Hanging in Wolverine City by Leslie Furlong

Best Investigation



Escape From the Lost Laboratories by Lester Ward

Best Use of Teleportation



The Belly of the Beast by Mike Monaco

Best Bio-Crawl



Crime and Punishment by Paul Cunningham

Best Science Fiction



Vermin Hollow by Rob

Best Evil Cult



Citadel of Evil by Stuart Robertson

Best Design



Another Knight Like This by Thom Wilson

Best Solo



Black Tom Muddye’s Treasure Map by Tim Hartin

Best Pirate

127947.description:
Maciej Szopa's "Eagles and Missiles" is a "what-if" wargame, which allows the players to play out a hypothetical strike of the Union State of Belorussia and Russia on Poland in the near future. The game is mainly concerned on the air aspect of such a conflict. Land battles, naval operations and special forces are included, but serve mainly as a background of the air war.

The Polish player manages his squadrons and sends them against enemy troop concentrations with bombers and ground-attack aircraft, engages the enemy aicraft with his fighters, and decides about the use of his air-defence assets... hoping for the timely arrival of NATO squadrons coming to his aid.

The "Agresor" commands ground forces, supports them with his aircraft squadrons and tries to destroy the Polish airforce, or at least take out its airbases.

The idea behind Eagles and Missiles is based on scenarios being considered by the Polish staff and tested on big field war games such as: Anakonda and Dragon. Like in the real-world simulations the invasion is performed from three directions: the Baltic (naval invasion), Kaliningrad District and Belorussia. The main objective of the attack is the Polish "lifeline" of Upper Silesia, Warsaw and Gdansk.

Contents:

Rulebook in Polish and English
60 counters
3 decks of cards (Russian, Polish and world opinion / NATO reaction)
Playing board dipicting the territory of Poland and neighbouring countries

Playing time is 60-90 minutes

---

"Orły i Rakiety" autorstwa Macieja Szopy to pierwsza gra planszowa podejmująca temat współczesnej wojny na terytorium Polski. Nareszcie można będzie sprawdzić w praktyce jakie możliwości ma nasza armia i czy jest w stanie obronić kraj, a przynajmniej utrzymać jego część zanim do akcji wkroczą sojusznicy. Gra skupiona jest przede wszystkim na walkach lotniczych nad Polską. Walki lądowe, operacje morskie, a nawet działania wojsk specjalnych także nie zostały pominięte ale stanowią jedynie tło do właściwej rozgrywki.

Gracz polski zarządza eskadrami samolotów posyłając je do boju w celu powstrzymywania wrogich ugrupowań lądowych (bombowce i samoloty szturmowe), zwalczania eskadr lotniczych przeciwnika (myśliwce) a także decyduje o wykorzystaniu naziemnych środków obrony przeciwlotniczej. Ponadto decyduje o kierunkach uderzeń przybywających Polakom z odsieczą eskadr natowskich. "Agresor" dowodzi siłami naziemnymi atakującymi poszczególne terytoria naszego kraju, wspiera natarcia lotnictwem i stara się zlikwidować polskie eskadry lub przynajmniej pozbawić je dogodnych lotnisk.

Pomysł gry opiera się na scenariuszach rozpatrywanych w polskich sztabach i trenowanych na poligonach, na wielkich ćwiczeniach polowych: Anakonda czy Dragon. Tak jak podczas prawdziwych symulacji uderzenia na Polskę są wyprowadzane z Bałtyku (desant), Okręgu Kaliningradzkiego i Białorusi, a głównym celem jest tak zwana polska "linia życia": Górny Śląsk, Warszawa i Trójmiasto.

Zawartość pudełka:

Instrukcja (dwujęzyczna),
zestaw 60 żetonów,
3 talie kart (rosyjska, polska i reakcji opinii publicznej oraz NATO),
duża (70 na 50 centymetrów) plansza przedstawiająca Polskę i kraje ościenne.

Czas rozgrywki to około 60-90 minut.
127947.name: Eagles & Missiles

127948.name: Eine Fahrt durch den Spreewald
127948.description: Objective: Be the first moving up to field 100- moving by turn - throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a marked space follow instructions.

127949.name: London Bridge
127949.description:
London Brodge is a simple marble shooting game for points. "London Bridge" in this case is a pasteboard picture of the bridge with four arches. From left to right the arches score 1, 4, 3, and 2 points.

From the box top:

Directions
Place the Bridge on the floor with the supports behind.
The game is for each player to shoot the marbles in turn, those passing under the arches score the number thereon.
The player making the highest score wins.

127950.name: The Nature
127950.description:
From the rule sheet

Wake up your environmental Protection consciousness

The Nature is easy to learn and quick to play. It's best for four or more players, though you can play with three people or more than five. The game aims to help players developing the consciousness of environment protection through fun and enjoyment.

Object to the game:
The object is to get living animal cards as many as you can in each round. Points score on the cards in player's "Zoo" card pile but minus points in the player's "Tomb" card pile.

Game play:
Player started with 5 cards. Each round he can 1) play a card; 2) draw a card and discard a card into his "Tomb" card pile.

When every player has play one card, the round is over. The greatest card of the latest colour will be the winner of that round. The winner can collect all the cards and place them into his "Zoo" card pile.

Game end when the last card is drawn from the deck.

127951.name: ROLLA-STRIKE
127951.description:
The world's first 14 sided bowling ball.

The fascinating Tetrakaideccahedronnocube... Just call me "TET."

There are 10 frames to each game and the player who has the highest score at the end wins. Each player has to complete frame 1 before the play moves on to frame 2 and so on. Maximum score per two rolls is 10. A spare is 10 points. A white dot on the first roll counts as a strike and no second roll is taken. It is pretty straight forward.

Equipment sold as a unit for playing a game simulating bowling by TET Leisuretime Concepts, Inc. in Arcadia, CA, 91006.

Similar games:

Bowling Dice
Bowl and Score
Bowl-A-Strike
Spare Time Bowling

127952.name: Terapia
127952.description:
Terapia

It is composed of a quad-fold board, the rules are printed on the back side of the box, 6 pawns (black, orange, red, blue, green, yellow) and 600 question cards. Themed on medical science, all questions are about medical (but not psychological) affairs.

The game goal is to be the first to move your pawn along the complete circle on the board from your starting color rectangle to the same position. There is a single pile of cards in the center of the board. Rectangles and cards are identified with 3, 2 or 1 dots. The player at your right asks you the question on the upper card of the pile. You must give right answer to the card question to be able to advance a single rectangle or 3 or 2 if dots stated in your actual position match the current question card dots. That has a maximum of three consecutive advances. Then the turn goes to the player at your right. If you fail a question the pawn moved is the one belonging to the player who asked the question.

127953.name: Tierpark Spiel
127953.description:
Objective: Be the first moving up to field 60
- moving by turn -
throw the die and move according rolled number; ending on a marked space (15x) follow instructions.

127954.name: One Page Dungeon Contest 2012: Winners
127954.description:
From One Page Dungeon Contest 2012 website:

Judges had one month to read all the submissions and another two weeks to discuss the result.

Here’s how we determined the winners:

Every judge nominated twenty entries and proposed a category or tag for each.
We prepared a list of the entries that got three or more nominations. These are the nominations.
Every judge again picked five entries from this smaller list.
All entries getting three or more votes are the judge’s picks.
We tried to make sure that every judge had at least three of his picks in the final list. Judge with an eclectic taste may find that not many of their nominations made it into this list. As the idea is to not only reflect popular opinion but to also capture some of the more eclectic entries out there, judges may add additional submission to the judge’s picks until we feel that every judge is well represented. We’ll try to aim for three entries per judge.
Based on the categories proposed in the first step, we assigned a category to each entry on the list.
The result was our release candidate 1. Judges got to check whether their favorites are still on the list.
We fix omissions and rename categories until we’re happy. This is our release candidate 2.
We revise everything until we’re happy. We have our list of winners!




Winners:

Winning Category
